nodes.bodyText: Maybe use withFilter as we already have withHint and withLock ?

We could argue about this. hint doesn't represent an action: we don't want the result to be a hint, and lock has an immediacy that isn't true, because the results are locked later.
OTOH, filter is an action that doesn't sound wrong even if applied immediately.
So I could argue for filter instead of withFilter but the reasoning is not obvious, and withFilter would be more regular. OTOH, we have page and range and not atPage and atRange.
So, not sure at all either way, TBH.

OK, no need to argue, name it as you prefere ;)
Naming is hard ...
I'll leave it like this, but I don't feel strongly either way.

We didn't lazily instantiate the hint Map.
If you think it worth it, can you refactor the hint Map to be lazily instantiated for coherence sake ?
It's something I like to do for <10% use-cases just in case. You can do it for the other stuff if you want or wait until a later refactor. No rush.
Oh, sure, I can add it here.
Done.
We usually describe the return type as this query, modified
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -148,6 +152,53 @@ interface PanacheQuery { */ fun withHint(hintName: String, value: Any): PanacheQuery + /** + *

+ * Enables a Hibernate filter during fetching of results for this query. Your filter must be declared + * with [FilterDef] on your entity or package, and enabled with [Filter] on your entity. + *

+ * WARNING: setting filters can only be done on the underlying Hibernate [Session] and so this + * will modify the session's filters for the duration of obtaining the results (not while building + * the query). Enabled filters will be removed from the session afterwards, but no effort is made to + * preserve filters enabled on the session outside of this API. + * + * @param filterName The name of the filter to enable + * @param parameters The set of parameters for the filter, if the filter requires parameters + * @return this query

nodes.bodyText: Ah, OK.

nodes.bodyText:
This is not a bug but a feature ;)
Maybe testIssue9036 or testFilter ?
Who cares, really? The issue number is what matters.

Me ? But OK it's nitpicking ;)
I don't care about issue number for what is not a bug.
Let's keep it if you want.
Can we make this a default? Would some typing later on :)
It's only used here, I don't see the point. It's in the JDK that this interface belongs :(
True
Damn Kotlin and your when keyword...
You need to be careful man... 😆
It's a risky job…
